captions.text: Here's' how you can become the coolest person on the block by building a device to make it rain candy!

I started this project with a trip to my home
improvement store for these PVC parts.

I'm gonna get the hard stuff out of the
way, so I'll measure different lengths of

schedule 40 PVC pipe and start cutting. I'm
mainly using 2" and 1" pipe for the

cannon, and 1 1/4" pipe for the detonator.
A chop saw worked well for me, but

I had to be careful because sometimes things
like that happen.

All the pipe is now cut to the lengths I want,
and before I glue the pieces in place

permanently, I'm gonna dry fit them all
together to see how they fit. My design

is for 2 separate 12" air tanks, joined together
with 1" pipe, and connecting to an

in-line sprinkler valve. I'm also gonna
add a manual ball valve and an end cap

that I'll thread a pneumatic adaptor onto
later. This 90 degree elbow will be my

base for a 2 foot tube of 2" PVC pipe that
will act as my cannon barrel.

It's looking really good and I'm very happy
with the design so it's time to glue it up.

I'll use some purple primer to get the PVC
ready for gluing, making sure to put a
coating on all the parts that will be connected.

Now I've finished gluing it back together
using PVC cement and am adding some

thread tape to these connector nipples to
ensure an air tight seal. I expect this

system will be pressurized around 135 PSI
and this should help prevent leaks.

It's time for a pressure test. I'm gonna
start around 60 PSI and test for leaks,
then slowly work my way up over 100.

I've closed off the manual valve and disconnected
the air hose and I don't hear

any air leaking, so I'm going to test the
sprinkler valve release by shorting it out

on this 9 volt battery. It's actually a 24
volt valve, but a single 9 volt battery seems
to work fine for this purpose.

And the valve works great, so it's time to
wire up the detonator.

I'll take the 1 1/4" cap and drill a hole
just big enough to insert a

momentary switch, and then I'll drill a 1/8"
hole in the bottom cap, to feed my

wire through. This is doorbell wire and I'll
tie it in a knot to prevent it from pulling

back through the cap again. Now I can add
the 1 1/4" x 4" pipe body to the
base, and then prep the wires for a good connection.

I'll wire the momentary switch in series with
the battery and sprinkler valve,

then give it a quick test to verify it's all
working correctly. Perfect! It's all working

great so I'll secure the switch, and tuck
the battery and wires into the detonator body.

Now I'm wrapping the wire around some scrap
1" pipe, it to give it a neat

coiled look, then I'll get to work on a wad
for the barrel.

This is the piece that will push the candy
up and out, and I'm going to make it out

of these plastic cups. I'll cut the bottom
quarter inch off the bigger cup, and then

shave about quarter inch from the top of a
3oz cup. When joined together they

make a perfect fit into the 2" barrel and
when it's time to load the candy, I'll push

them to the bottom with a makeshift ramrod.
These are super cheap and

surprisingly durable, but still gentle enough
to convert this cannon into an

Epic water balloon launcher! Look for that
in another video!

Alright, this system is looking pretty good,
but I want it to look amazing. So I'll

clean off the UPC stickers with some adhesive
remover, and then
spray paint it red and black.

Everything is back together, and I'm really
happy with how this is looking.

The daunting question now is, will it work,
or was this all for nothing?
Time to test it out.

The plastic cups are in place, and I'm using
these jelly candies for practice.
It's ready to go in 3 … 2 … 1 … FIRE!
Amazing!

These candies shot up around 100 feet in the
air, and completely covered the back

yard, making an exciting candy hunt for my
kids, and a hit novelty at the birthday party.
Well I'll call that an epic success!
If you liked this project, perhaps you'll like some of my others.
Check them out at  www.thekingofrandom.com

comments.text:
+andrew gilroy Here is how you can become the coolest person on the block 
by building a device to rain candy. I started this project with a trip to 
my home improvement store for these pvc parts. I am going the hard stuff 
out of the way so I'll measure different lengths of schedule 40 pvc pipe 
and start cutting. I am mainly using 2 inch and one inch pvc pipe for the 
cannon and one and 1 quarter inch pipe for the detonator. A chop saw worked 
well for me but I had to be careful because sometimes things like that 
happen. The pipe is now out to the lengths I want and before I glue these 
prices in place permanently I'm going to to fit them all together to see 
how they fit. My design is for two separate 12 inch air tanks joined 
together with one inch pipe and connecting To a inline sprinkler valve I am 
also going to add a manual ball valve and an end cap that I will thread a 
pneumatic adapter onto later this 90 degree elbow will be my base for a 2 
foot tube of 2 inch pvc pipe that will act as my cannon barrel it looking 
very good and I am very happy with the design so it is time to glue it up I 
will use some purple primer to get the pvc ready for gluing making sure to 
put a coating on all the parts that will be connected now I've finished 
gluing it back together using pvc cement and am adding some thread tape to 
these connected nipples to ensure an air tight seal. I expect this system 
will be pressurized around 135 psi and this should help prevent leaks it's 
time for a pressure test I'm gonna start around 60 psi and test for leaks 
then slowly make my way up over 100. I've closed off the manual valve and 
disconnected the air hose and I don't hear any air leaking so I'm going to 
test the sprinkler valve release by shorting it out on this 9 volt battery 
it is actually a 24 volt valve but a single 9 volt battery seems to work 
fine for this purpose and the valve works great so it's time to wire up the 
detonator I will take the 1 1/4" cap and drill a hole just big enough to 
insert a momentary switch and then drill a 1/8" hole in the bottom cap to 
feed My wire through this is doorbell wire and I'll tie a knot to prevent 
it from pulling back through the cap again now I can add the 1 1/4 x4" pipe 
body to the base and prep the wires for a good connection I will wire the 
momentary switch in series with the battery and sprinkler valve then give 
it a quick test to verify its all working correctly perfect it's all 
working great so I'll secure the switch and tuck the battery wires into the 
detonator body no I'm wrapping the wire around some scrap 1" pipe it to 
give it a neat coiled look then I'll get to work on a wad for the barrel 
this is the price that will push the candy up and out and I'm going to make 
it out of this plastic cups I will cut the bottom quarter inch off the 
bigger and then shave about a quarter inch from the top of a 3oz cup when 
joined together they make a perfect 2" barrel and when it time to load the 
candy I'll push them to the bottom with a makeshift ramrod thee are super 
cheap and surprisingly durable but still gentle enough to convert this 
cannon into an epic water ballon launcher look for that in another video 
alright this system is looking pretty good but I want it to look amazing so 
I'll clean off the upc stickers with some adhesive remover and the spray 
paint it red and black every thing is back together and I'm really happy 
with how this is looking the daunting question now is will it work or was 
it all for nothing? Time to test it out the plastic cups are in place and 
I'm using these jelly candies for practice it's ready to go in 3 2 1 fire 
amazing These candies shot up around 100 feet in the air and completely 
covered back yard making an exciting candy hunt for my kids and hit novelty 
at the birthday party well I will call that a epic success if you liked 
this project perhaps you will like some of my others check them out at the 
king of random .com

it a quick test to verify its all working correctly perfect it's all 
working great so I'll secure the switch and tuck the battery wires into the 
detonator body no I'm wrapping the wire around some scrap 1" pipe it to 
give it a neat coiled look then I'll get to work on a wad for the barrel 
this is the price that will push the candy up and out and I'm going to make 
it out of this plastic cups I will cut the bottom quarter inch off the 
bigger and then shave about a quarter inch from the top of a 3oz cup when 
joined together they make a perfect 2" barrel and when it time to load the 
candy I'll push them to the bottom with a makeshift ramrod thee are super 
cheap and surprisingly durable but still gentle enough to convert this 
cannon into an epic water ballon launcher look for that in another video 
alright this system is looking pretty good but I want it to look amazing so 
I'll clean off the upc stickers with some adhesive remover and the spray 
paint it red and black every thing is back together and I'm really happy 
with how this is looking the daunting question now is will it work or was 
it all for nothing? Time to test it out the plastic cups are in place and 
I'm using these jelly candies for practice it's ready to go in 3 2 1 fire 
amazing These candies shot up around 100 feet in the air and completely 
covered back yard making an exciting candy hunt for my kids and hit novelty 
at the birthday party well I will call that a epic success if you liked 
this project perhaps you will like some of my others check them out at the 
king of random . Com

comments.text: Whatever, random guy on the internet.
comments.author: Tyler Paul

comments.text:
it's not a production item and it's not something that even comes with 
instructions on how to build it.  it's just a hobbyist screwing around, and 
you're playing the typical internet jerk role of sucking all of the fun out 
of everything.  I'm bored with you.
comments.author: Tom Ligman

comments.text:
It's bad practice, if nothing else. I would never use water piping for my 
machine pneumatics, the potential to put a chunk in one of the assembly 
techs is too damn high.
comments.author: Tyler Paul

comments.text:
it's not a permanent installation and he's not even at half the pressure. 
 it'll be scrapped in favor of another project in 2 days.
comments.author: Tom Ligman

comments.text:
Those are ratings for 73°F water pressure of installed pipe sections.
I would not use sch40 pipe for portable compressed air storage, because it 
does not hold up to even light wear, temperature fluctuations under 
pressure, or shock.
But hey, it's not my face at risk.
comments.author: Tyler Paul

comments.text:
now that I actually scrolled down, 4" schedule 40 is rated to  220psi, 
which is quite a lot of overhead for this project.  The smaller diameter 
pipes are all much higher rated than that.
comments.author: Tom Ligman

comments.text:
http://www.harvel.com/technical-support-center/product-specifications/pvc-pipe-schedule-40 
- minimum 120psi rating for schedule 40 PVC pipe, possibly up to 800psi. 
 That's plenty.
comments.author: Tom Ligman

comments.text: I see what you are saying.
comments.author: Clint Cochrane

comments.text:
But he's using the base as the air tank as well, and pressurizing it up to 
100psi.
PVC isn't rated for that. The CO2 bottle is rated for 2000 to 3000psi, 
cheap, and can be adapted to the same air compressor fitting to charge it 
up to 100psi safely.
comments.author: Tyler Paul

comments.text:
+Tyler Paul I don't think this needs high pressure. I feel like it's made 
for kids and you want more volume of product than pressure
comments.author: Clint Cochrane

comments.text:
Hmm. Not very sturdy a design.
Also, PVC is notorious for having low pressure strength, it'd be safer to 
just use a paintball marker CO2 bottle.
